text: in the tech business a simple phrase can
often mask the subject of considerable
richness and complexity today i'll talk
to joe vicaro of citrix to learn more
about desktop virtualization
speaking of virtualization i'll be
speaking with eric schultz of the ec2
team about virtual private cloud later
in the show
tell me a bit about what you do for
citrix at citrix i'm part of the product
management team in our desktops and apps
group where i help lead the strategy
around the intersection of desktops and
apps and cloud so i hear this phrase
desktop virtualization all the time and
i'm not really sure i understand what it
means could you tell me a bit about that
you know citrix's vision is really to
enable people to be able to work and
play from anywhere
and where desktop virtualization comes
into that is enabling them to get access
to the core set of windows apps and
desktops that they need to be productive
from anywhere anytime on any device
what's really happening on the server
side before all this content gets out to
the device so at the heart of our
desktop virtualization strategy is a
product called zendesktop zendesktop is
the
leader in desktop virtualization with
hundreds of thousands of
seats deployed serving millions of
different users from that what we
deliver is the windows app and desktop
that is then delivered down to the
device over what we call our hdx
technology that hdx technology really
serves to be able to deliver that high
definition experience to deliver that
windows app and desktop to the different
device tell me a bit about how the cloud
factors into all this citrix has been
working in the cloud for a number of
years we've seen this transition
a number of years ago when we introduced
the first the citrix service provider
program in 2009 from then now we have
over 2500 service providers that are
delivering desktops and apps as a
service many of those who are actually
using amazon to be able to power their
back-end infrastructure
and then as well in 2012 what we saw is
the rise of this as a service and
introduced our project avalon citrix's
strategy to be able to actually deliver
desktops and apps in the cloud era tell
me a little bit more specifically how
this factors into aws like
what do i what kind of apps do i run in
aws how do i connect what kind of
security issues do i need to worry about
those kinds of things yeah a number of
years ago we began collaborating with
amazon and actually built reference
architectures to take our core product
zen app that delivers that
published apps and desktops and be able
to deliver that into amazon web services
inside of a customer's vpc now this is
more than just being able to say take a
reference architecture and documentation
for how to deploy it we're actually
going so far as building out cloud
formation scripts to help them to
automate the actual deployment and
configuration setup of the entire citrix
environment now we do all of that within
a
vpc environment and then using our cloud
bridge technology help customers then to
link that vpc back to the enterprise
data center where they might have
existing apps and data as well as
authentication services from active
directory and others do your customers
find the availability of launching this
on aws is that a strong positive for
them what we see in really the value and
why we work closely with amazon uh
within our desktop virtualization is our
customers are trying to go faster
they're trying to expand and by
deploying zen app and and desktop on aws
it allows them to reach new users in new
geographies be able to reduce the
overall cost of their infrastructure as
well as be able to just leverage the
broad capabilities that amazon brings to
the table where would you see all this
going in the next six to 12 months let's
say you know the first is not just the
six or 12 months but what's happening
before that so we have customers that
are doing this today across a number of
key verticals including our healthcare
government finance education
manufacturing that are doing this today
as well as then in the future what we
see is is that beyond zendesk top 7 our
latest release being able to further
innovate and integrate with amazon to
provide near
native provisioning to amazon ec2 s3 and
the rest of the key attributes so that
we can further simplify the process for
delivering desktop virtualization in
amazon that sounds great i really
appreciate you taking the time to come
by and speak with us today and wish you
all the best with your products great
thanks jeff thank you
let's turn to our zen to the cloud
segment
thanks for joining me today eric can you
tell me about what virtual private cloud
is well virtual private cloud is virtual
networking in amazon web services and it
lets you build a virtual networking
environment that closely resembles the
same type of network that you might have
on a physical premise so you can build a
network you can build subnets you could
have route tables and gateways and
network apples anything that you might
have in that physical environment you
can now do up in the cloud to mimic that
same environment that you have at home
what kind of services and resources are
available within a vpc
you can do anything in the vpc that you
can do in ec2 classic today so you can
launch instances you can do spot
instances reserved instances you can run
the emr jobs you can run dynamodb
redshift you can access your s3
resources
you can run
rds and elastic hash and elastic load
balancing and a vpc if you want and how
much ip space does a customer get in ppc
you can have up to 65 000 ip addresses
in a single vpc
and as little as 16 ip addresses in a
vpc
can you tell me about some of the more
interesting use cases that customers
have for vpc
sure you can stand up public-facing web
instances like web servers in a public
subnet with public ip addresses and
those can talk to back-end database
servers that might be in a private
subnet and those database servers don't
have any public ip addresses so those
are more in a dmz environment so it
provides a little more security for that
connection
well i think that's all the questions i
had actually it was really great
chatting with you today eric and really
want to thank you so much for for coming
and joining us thank you so much for
